channel.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

No? It makes perfect sense.

@First & second part:
Unless your design requests the use of a final modifier, for example: when instantiating an event and setting parameter values’, they must be final. (FOR EXAMPLE!)

@Third part:
Was directed at fields declared final that should not be, was just added on for the sake of explaining.

@Forth part:
Maybe he should have said specifically: “wherever you have a constant field” and not “wherever you can”

So no, his post was misleading which is why I explained. I wasn’t directing anything in my post to the OP; it was directed at asshole_rule for his post.

Read full topic

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:25, topic:469760”][quote author=relexlawl link=topic=587048.msg4168378#msg4168378 date=1353966092]

Check conventions and use final modifier where you can.

Good job.

No.

Edit: explained because you would have asked me to anyways.

Unless your design requests it, don’t use final. e.g, within an event, parameters used or set within must be final.
You cannot manipulate a state so therefore you must keep constructing a new state to accommodate the changes, this is when you use the final modifier, not ‘wherever you can’

[hr]

lul what are you talking about.
[/quote]

What isn’t clear?[/quote]

Unless your design requests it, don’t use final. e.g, within an event, parameters used or set within must be final.
You cannot manipulate a state so therefore you must keep constructing a new state to accommodate the changes, this is when you use the final modifier, not ‘wherever you can’

^ Have you seriously read what you wrote?

If you really need me to break it down for you:

Unless your design requests it - What the hell is this supposed to mean? Unless your design ‘requests’ it…

don’t use final. e.g, within an event, parameters used or set within must be final. - Final modifiers’ purpose is so it cannot be changed, i.e for constants, what you’re saying here, is that you should only use final modifiers for events? wuut?

You cannot manipulate a state so therefore you must keep constructing a new state to accommodate the changes - Again…What the hell is this even suppose to mean?

this is when you use the final modifier, not ‘wherever you can’ - No, I repeat, final modifiers’ purpose is so it cannot be changed, so you would use it wherever you need a constant.

So, he was right, OP should’ve used final modifiers for the arrays and the other ints (constants) he has such as timer and damage, at least for conventions/user-friendly purposes.

Read full topic

Edit: explained because you would have asked me to anyways.

Unless your design requests it, don’t use final. e.g, within an event, parameters used or set within must be final.
You cannot manipulate a state so therefore you must keep constructing a new state to accommodate the changes, this is when you use the final modifier, not ‘wherever you can’

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @mr_extremez mr extremez
item.description:
@mr_extremez wrote:

Is this good? And thanks for all the help btw guys :).

[code=java]package server.game.content.traveling;

import server.Server;
import server.game.players.Client;
import server.task.Task;

/**

  • Desert
  • @author Andrew
    */

public class Desert {

public static final int[] DRINKABLES = {1823, 1825, 1827, 1829};//add all drinkables here
private static final int DAMAGE = 4;//change the damage here
private static final int TIMER = 45000;//change the time you get hurt
private static final int TIMER_2 = 90000;
public static final int DESERT_TICKS = 75;
private static int a = -1;
private boolean eventExecuted;

public boolean isEventExecuted() {
       return eventExecuted;
}

public void setEventExecuted(boolean eventExecuted) {
       this.eventExecuted = eventExecuted;
}

public static void callHeat(final Client c) {
        Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(DESERT_TICKS, false) {
                @Override
                protected void execute() {
                        if (!c.inDesert()) {
                                stop();
                                c.getDesert().setEventExecuted(false);
                                return;
                        }
                        if (c.disconnected) {
                            stop();
                            return;
                        }
                        if (System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > TIMER && c.inDesert()) {
                                checkWaterskin(c);
                                c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                c.playerLevel[3] -= DAMAGE;
                                c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                        } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837 && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > TIMER_2 && c.inDesert()) {
                                checkWaterskin(c);
                                c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                c.playerLevel[3] -= DAMAGE;
                                c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                        } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {//for glitchers
                                c.isDead = true;
                                c.getDesert().setEventExecuted(false);
                                stop();
                                return;
                        }
                }
        });
}
		
public static void checkWaterskin(final Client c) {
	if (c.getItems().playerHasItem(1831, 1)) {//empty waterskin
		return;
	}
	for (int i = 0; i < CACTUS.length; i++) {
		 if (c.getItems().playerHasItem(CACTUS[i][1])) {
		    	a = i;
	           }
	        }
	if (a == -1) {
		c.sendMessage("You don't have any waterskins.");
	    return;
	}
	c.getItems().deleteItem(CACTUS[a][1], 1);
	c.getItems().addItem(CACTUS[a][0], 1);
	c.sendMessage("You drink your waterskin.");
	c.startAnimation(829);
	c.lastDesert = 0;
}	

private static int[][] CACTUS = {
		{1825, 1823},//waterskin 3
		{1827, 1825},//waterskin 2
		{1829, 1827},//waterskin 1
		{1831, 1829}//waterskin 0
};

public static void cutCactus(Client c) {
	if (!c.getItems().playerHasItem(946, 1)) {
		c.sendMessage("You can't fill your waterskin without a knife.");
	}
	if (c.getItems().playerHasItem(1823, 1)) {
		c.sendMessage("Your waterskin is already full.");
	}
    for (int i = 0; i < CACTUS.length; i++) {
        if (c.getItems().playerHasItem(CACTUS[i][0])) {
        	a = i;
       }
    }
    if (a == -1) {
        c.sendMessage("You don't have any waterskins to fill.");
        return;
    }
    if (c.getItems().freeSlots() < 1) {
        c.sendMessage("You do not have enough inventory slots to do that.");
        return;
    }
    c.getItems().addItem(CACTUS[a][1], 1);
    c.getItems().deleteItem(CACTUS[a][0], 1);
	c.getPA().addSkillXP(10, c.playerWoodcutting);
	c.sendMessage("You fill your waterskin.");
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Int Bauk, post:9, topic:469760”][code] /**
* If the event is executed or not
*/
private boolean eventExecuted;

    /**
     * 75 ticks = 45 seconds
     */
    public static final int DESERT_TICKS = 75;

    /**
     * Executes a player-specifc task to be executed every 45 seconds (75 ticks)
     * 
     * @param c
     *            The player
     */
    public void callHeat(final Client c) {
            Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(DESERT_TICKS, false) {
                    @Override
                    protected void execute() {
                            if (!c.inDesert()) {
                                    setEventExecuted(false);
                                    stop();
				return;
                            }
                            if (c.isDisconnected()) {
                                    stop();
				return;
                            }

                            if (c.inDesert()) {
                                    checkWaterskin(c);
                                    c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                    c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                    c.playerLevel[3] -= damage;
                                    c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                            } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833
                                            && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835
                                            && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837
                                            && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer2
                                            && c.inDesert()) {
                                    checkWaterskin(c);
                                    c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                    c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                    c.playerLevel[3] -= damage;
                                    c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                            } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {// for glitchers
                                    c.isDead = true;
                            }
                    }
            });
    }

    /**
     * @return if the event is executed or not
     */
    public boolean isEventExecuted() {
            return eventExecuted;
    }

    /**
     * @param eventExecuted
     *            setting if the event is executed or not
     */
    public void setEventExecuted(boolean eventExecuted) {
            this.eventExecuted = eventExecuted;
    }[/code]

fixed.[/quote]
what exactly did you fix…

EDIT: Oh the return, the method still loops even if the task has stopped?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

[code] /**
* If the event is executed or not
*/
private boolean eventExecuted;

    /**
     * 75 ticks = 45 seconds
     */
    public static final int DESERT_TICKS = 75;

    /**
     * Executes a player-specifc task to be executed every 45 seconds (75 ticks)
     * 
     * @param c
     *            The player
     */
    public void callHeat(final Client c) {
            Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(DESERT_TICKS, false) {
                    @Override
                    protected void execute() {
                            if (!c.inDesert()) {
                                    setEventExecuted(false);
                                    stop();
				return;
                            }
                            if (c.isDisconnected()) {
                                    stop();
				return;
                            }

                            if (c.inDesert()) {
                                    checkWaterskin(c);
                                    c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                    c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                    c.playerLevel[3] -= damage;
                                    c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                            } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833
                                            && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835
                                            && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837
                                            && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer2
                                            && c.inDesert()) {
                                    checkWaterskin(c);
                                    c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                    c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                    c.playerLevel[3] -= damage;
                                    c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                            } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {// for glitchers
                                    c.isDead = true;
                            }
                    }
            });
    }

            return eventExecuted;

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

mr extremez:

Thanks, I’ll try to do update it and do everything you said now. How often should I update it? 1800ms? And I added some stops and made them constants.

make sure your constants ARE_UPPERCASE_LIKE_THIS_TOO_FOR_CONVENTION. That’s not really what I had in mind, my process would involve rewriting more but, what I’m going to suggest way is easier and close enough.

Instead of using System timers

Why not just have the event check every 45 seconds, then deal the damage or not accordingly? And you could add a check to the start of your event to see if you are still logged in, and if not it stops the event with this, you would have to take the static modifier off your methods (which really isn’t needed) and create an instance of your class in the Client class.

So what I would do:

end of walking/region packet:

if(isInDesert() && !getDesert().isEventExecuted) { getDesert().callHeat(); getDesert().setEventExecuted(true); }

new methods/varibles for your class:

[code=java] /**
* If the event is executed or not
*/
private boolean eventExecuted;

    /**
     * 75 ticks = 45 seconds
     */
    public static final int DESERT_TICKS = 75;

    /**
     * Executes a player-specifc task to be executed every 45 seconds (75 ticks)
     * 
     * @param c
     *            The player
     */
    public void callHeat(final Client c) {
            Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(DESERT_TICKS, false) {
                    @Override
                    protected void execute() {
                            if (!c.inDesert()) {
                                    setEventExecuted(false);
                                    stop();
				return;
                            }
                            if (c.isDisconnected()) {
                                    stop();
				return;
                            }

                            if (c.inDesert()) {
                                    checkWaterskin(c);
                                    c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                    c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                    c.playerLevel[3] -= damage;
                                    c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                            } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833
                                            && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835
                                            && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837
                                            && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer2
                                            && c.inDesert()) {
                                    checkWaterskin(c);
                                    c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis();
                                    c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert.");
                                    c.playerLevel[3] -= damage;
                                    c.getPA().refreshSkill(3);
                            } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {// for glitchers
                                    c.isDead = true;
                            }
                    }
            });
    }

    /**
     * @return if the event is executed or not
     */
    public boolean isEventExecuted() {
            return eventExecuted;
    }

    /**
     * @param eventExecuted
     *            setting if the event is executed or not
     */
    public void setEventExecuted(boolean eventExecuted) {
            this.eventExecuted = eventExecuted;
    }[/code]

NOTE: You don’t have to add this, your code isn’t bad, I’m just trying to suggest other ways, I don’t mean to come across as an ass or anything.

Read full topic

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:4, topic:469760”]Good job, looks somewhat clean and from what I can tell your conventions aren’t bad either

time for some constructive criticism:

public static int[] drinkables = {1823, 1825, 1827, 1829};//add all drinkables here private static int damage = 4;//change the damage here private static int timer = 45000;//change the time you get hurt private static int timer2 = 90000;

make these constants, it would make more sense because these values are global variables that do not change their value at all within your class.

public static void callHeat(final Client c) { Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(1) { @Override protected void execute() { if (System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer && c.inDesert()) { checkWaterskin(c); c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert."); c.playerLevel[3] -= damage; c.getPA().refreshSkill(3); } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837 && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer2 && c.inDesert()) { checkWaterskin(c); c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert."); c.playerLevel[3] -= damage; c.getPA().refreshSkill(3); } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {//for glitchers c.isDead = true; } } }); }

You really shouldn’t be checking every 600ms to do a couple checks, I also see you aren’t calling ‘stop()’ on your tasks, this could lead to high memory usage. Why not try to utilize the walking packet/region packet with this rather than checking every 600ms?

Other than that looks good man, keep improving[/quote]

and when adding the stop() void, if there’s no body to the void don’t declare it as one. use as method.stop();, then add a return statement beneath it, to stop it looping through the method (had this when using task).

Read full topic

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @mr_extremez mr extremez
item.description:
@mr_extremez wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:4, topic:469760”]Good job, looks somewhat clean and from what I can tell your conventions aren’t bad either

time for some constructive criticism:

public static int[] drinkables = {1823, 1825, 1827, 1829};//add all drinkables here private static int damage = 4;//change the damage here private static int timer = 45000;//change the time you get hurt private static int timer2 = 90000;

make these constants, it would make more sense because these values are global variables that do not change their value at all within your class.

public static void callHeat(final Client c) { Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(1) { @Override protected void execute() { if (System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer && c.inDesert()) { checkWaterskin(c); c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert."); c.playerLevel[3] -= damage; c.getPA().refreshSkill(3); } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837 && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer2 && c.inDesert()) { checkWaterskin(c); c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert."); c.playerLevel[3] -= damage; c.getPA().refreshSkill(3); } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {//for glitchers c.isDead = true; } } }); }

You really shouldn’t be checking every 600ms to do a couple checks, I also see you aren’t calling ‘stop()’ on your tasks, this could lead to high memory usage. Why not try to utilize the walking packet/region packet with this rather than checking every 600ms?

Other than that looks good man, keep improving[/quote]Thanks, I’ll try to do update it and do everything you said now. How often should I update it? 1800ms? And I added some stops and made them constants.

Read full topic

item.title: Desert Heat || Cactus's ||Waterskins [Project Insanity]
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Good job, looks somewhat clean and from what I can tell your conventions aren’t bad either

time for some constructive criticism:

public static int[] drinkables = {1823, 1825, 1827, 1829};//add all drinkables here private static int damage = 4;//change the damage here private static int timer = 45000;//change the time you get hurt private static int timer2 = 90000;

make these constants, it would make more sense because these values are global variables that do not change their value at all within your class.

public static void callHeat(final Client c) { Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(1) { @Override protected void execute() { if (System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer && c.inDesert()) { checkWaterskin(c); c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert."); c.playerLevel[3] -= damage; c.getPA().refreshSkill(3); } else if (c.playerEquipment[c.playerChest] == 1833 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerLegs] == 1835 && c.playerEquipment[c.playerFeet] == 1837 && System.currentTimeMillis() - c.lastDesert > timer2 && c.inDesert()) { checkWaterskin(c); c.lastDesert = System.currentTimeMillis(); c.sendMessage("You've been damaged by the heat of the desert."); c.playerLevel[3] -= damage; c.getPA().refreshSkill(3); } else if (c.playerHitpoints < 0) {//for glitchers c.isDead = true; } } }); }

You really shouldn’t be checking every 600ms to do a couple checks, I also see you aren’t calling ‘stop()’ on your tasks, this could lead to high memory usage. Why not try to utilize the walking packet/region packet with this rather than checking every 600ms?

Other than that looks good man, keep improving
